intro: Rubus eluxatus var. trichocarpus, commonly known as the hairy-fruited blackberry, is a variant of the blackberry plant native to parts of Asia. It is characterized by its thorny stems and compound leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, aggregate fruits that are typically dark purple to black in color. It thrives in temperate climates and is often found in woodland areas or along stream banks. The hairy texture of its fruit is a distinguishing feature of this particular variety.
